subsection.title: Domain and Range

li.p: What kinds of input does a function accept?
What are all the possible outputs a function will produce?

subsection.p: In math we have our own vocabulary we use to ask these same questions. The set of inputs a function will accept is called the domain domain of the function. The set of possible outputs is called the range. range

introduction.p: Consider shopping online at a t-shirt company. Each t-shirt costs \$ 13.00, and each time you click on the add to shopping cart button, your account adds a charge for \$ 13.00.
Let C represent the cost in dollars of purchasing N t-shirts. Therefore, C = f(N).
What are the possible input values in this situation? In other words: what is the domain of the function f ?
What are the possible output values in this situation? In other words: what is the range of the function f ?

statement.p: T-shirt cost function: Enter the cost of buying N t-shirts.

li.p: Look at the inputs for N from the table.
Is it possible to buy 3.1415 t-shirts?
Is it possible to buy -7 t-shirts?
How would you classify all the possible input values?
This is the domain of our function.
Now look at all the outputs C from the table.
Is it possible that the cost will be \$ 14 or \$ 15 or \$ 16?
How would you classify all the output values?
This is the range of our function.
You can buy 0 t-shirts, or 1 or 2 or more, but you can't buy 1.5 t-shirts or 2.63 t-shirts. You can only buy a whole number of t-shirts, not fractions of shirts.
You also can't buy a negative number of t-shirts, so N can't be less than zero.

In math we say that the domain of our function is the set of all non-negative integers. This means the domain is the set: N = \{0, 1, 2, 3, \cdots \}. These are the only numbers that make sense for our function, the only numbers our function accepts.
If you don't add t-shirts to your online shopping cart, then N = 0, your cart will have no t-shirst and you won't pay anything, f(0) = 0.
If you choose N = 1 t-shirts you will pay \$ 13.00
At N = 2 you pay \$ 26.00
Notice you will never have a final checkout of \$ 10.00 or \$ 18.00. In fact, you will only pay in multiples of \$ 13.00 because, again, you can't buy fractions of a t-shirt.
What are all the possible output values of our function?
You can't purchase a negative amount and you can't buy fractions of a t-shirt
Therefore the range of our function is all non-negative integer multiples of 13:

subsection.p: Sometimes a function will only accept certain input values, or it may produce only certain kinds of outputs.
This function will take real number inputs, as long as the input is not negative (you can't take the square root of a negative number).
On the other hand, the square root function only produces outputs that are positive or zero.
By graphing the function, the domain and range become more apparent.
The figure shows the graph of f exists horizontally only from the origin and to the right. Therefore the domain of f is: x \geq 0.
The figure also shows the graph of f exists vertically from the origin and up. Therefore the range of f is: y \geq 0.
Note: Since the vertical axis is called y, it means that y = f(x). Think of f(x) as the machine that turns x values into y values. Therefore we can use f(x) or y when referring to the range.

assemblage.p: Important facts when determining the domain of a function:

li.p: You can't take the square root of negative numbers
You can't allow the denominator of a fraction to be zero.

example.title: The algebraic method of finding the domain of any function with a square root
example.p: Because we cannot take the square root of a negative number, we can set the expression under the root (called the radicand) greater than or equal to zero, and then isolate the variable. The result is the domain of the function.
Let f(x)=\sqrt{4x-9}. To find the domain, we set 4x-9 \geq 0 and isolate x.
So the domain of f is x \geq \frac{9}{4}

stack.p: The domain is the set of numbers which are greater than or equal to \frac{9}{4}, as shown in the graph. The x-intercept of the graph is the point \left(\frac{9}{4}, 0\right), and the graph extends to the right.
This technique is good only for determining the domain of a function. Finding the range requires other methods.

subsection.p: Identifying the domain and range of a function just by looking at its formula can be difficult. Knowing what to look for comes with experience.

Often, a good way to determine the domain and range of a function is to graph it. Make a graph on a graphing tool and try to identify where the function exists horizontally: this is the domain. Then try to identify where the function exists vertically: this is the range.
Be careful: the domain and range are not necessarily connected intervals. They may consist of different sections that together make up the entire domain or the entire range.
